citations.narrative:
Four incidents occurred in which enclosures did not protect birds from injury or predation:
--On March 8, 2024 during morning round observations a 4 year old male mandarin duck (ID# AV0619) was found
predated in the black swan pond enclosure. The pond enclosure located on the periphery of the zoo grounds adjacent to
an empty parking lot is not fully enclosed (i.e. open-air top) but it includes areas of dense foliage on opposite sides of the
pond as well as two shelters (i.e. a large dog crate as well as an A-frame structure) for safety. A hawk was previously
seen nesting near the zoo grounds and presumed by zoo staff to be the predator involved in this case.
--On June 13, 2024 during morning round observations a zoo keeper discovered a rat snake in one of the sun parakeet
nest boxes where two sun parakeets were missing (i.e. 13 year old male #AV0431 & 14 year old female #AV0429). Staff
confirmed predation by scanning and detecting the missing birds' microchips inside the rat snake. The enclosure consists
of 1x1 inch metal fencing walls and roofing which are contiguous with each other and this is the first incident of a predator
breach to this enclosure. The enclosure was thoroughly inspected by zoo staff for point of entry for the snake and no area
of compromised integrity was identified.
--On July 10, 2024 during morning round observations a 15 year old male Chilean flamingo (#AV0496) was found
deceased in its enclosure with a foot caught in a split gap on one of two 5-foot vertical wood pillars/posts. The vertical
posts have an approximate 6-inch flat cut diameter top surface and staff indicated the flamingos were never observed to
use these posts for perching. The wood pillars/posts are only intended to keep the giant tortoises from entering the
flamingo area of the exhibit. Corrective action of trimming the posts as well as increased frequency of enclosure integrity
checks were implemented prior to the time of the inspection on October 24, 2024.
--On August 3, 2024 the keeper opened the 6 inch diameter water drain of the black swan pool to empty it for routine
maintenance. When the keeper returned to complete the pool maintenance the 1.5 year old female black swan (#AV0831)
was found deceased with her head inside the drain. The cause of death was determined to be drowning due to necropsy
findings of water in the bird’s lungs. Corrective action of covering the pool drain with a screen cover during pool
maintenance was implemented prior to the time of inspection on October 24, 2024.
Complete corrections by January 28, 2025 by ensuring housing facilities are kept in good repair, protect the birds from
injury, and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.

On May 5, 2024 a patron reported to zoo personnel that they saw an agouti (a rodent species) bite the 11 year old male
Campine chicken (#AV0544) that was housed in the same enclosure. The chicken was the only bird housed in this
enclosure and had been housed its entire life with 3 cavies and 2 agouti without prior incident. Once notified, zoo staff
quickly retrieved the chicken for medical assessment. The veterinarian elected to euthanize the chicken due to poor
prognosis from the injuries it received. Birds may be subjected to adverse effects on welfare, health, or injury if housed
with other animals that are not compatible. Facilities must ensure birds are housed with other compatible animals that do
not prevent access to food, water, or shelter by individual animals, and are not known to be hazardous to the health and
well-being of each other.
Corrective action was implemented prior to the inspection on October 24, 2024 and avian species are no longer housed in
this enclosure.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
Four incidents occurred in which enclosures did not protect birds from injury or predation: 
 --On March 8, 2024 during morning round observations a 4 year old male mandarin duck (ID# AV0619) was found 
predated in the black swan pond enclosure. The pond enclosure located on the periphery of the zoo grounds adjacent to 
an empty parking lot is not fully enclosed (i.e. open-air top) but it includes areas of dense foliage on opposite sides of the 
pond as well as two shelters (i.e. a large dog crate as well as an A-frame structure) for safety. A hawk was previously 
seen nesting near the zoo grounds and presumed by zoo staff to be the predator involved in this case.  
 --On June 13, 2024 during morning round observations a zoo keeper discovered a rat snake in one of the sun parakeet 
nest boxes where two sun parakeets were missing (i.e. 13 year old male #AV0431 & 14 year old female #AV0429). Staff 
confirmed predation by scanning and detecting the missing birds' microchips inside the rat snake. The enclosure consists 
of 1x1 inch metal fencing walls and roofing which are contiguous with each other and this is the first incident of a predator 
breach to this enclosure. The enclosure was thoroughly inspected by zoo staff for point of entry for the snake and no area 
of compromised integrity was identified. 
 --On July 10, 2024 during morning round observations a 15 year old male Chilean flamingo (#AV0496) was found 
deceased in its enclosure with a foot caught in a split gap on one of two 5-foot vertical wood pillars/posts. The vertical 
posts have an approximate 6-inch flat cut diameter top surface and staff indicated the flamingos were never observed to 
use these posts for perching. The wood pillars/posts are only intended to keep the giant tortoises from entering the 
flamingo area of the exhibit. Corrective action of trimming the posts as well as increased frequency of enclosure integrity 
checks were implemented prior to the time of the inspection on October 24, 2024. 
 --On August 3, 2024 the keeper opened the 6 inch diameter water drain of the black swan pool to empty it for routine 
maintenance. When the keeper returned to complete the pool maintenance the 1.5 year old female black swan (#AV0831) 
was found deceased with her head inside the drain. The cause of death was determined to be drowning due to necropsy 
findings of water in the bird’s lungs. Corrective action of covering the pool drain with a screen cover during pool 
maintenance was implemented prior to the time of inspection on October 24, 2024. 
 
Complete corrections by January 28, 2025 by ensuring housing facilities are kept in good repair, protect the birds from 
injury, and restrict other animals from entering that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. 
3.160(b)  Critical

Compatibility and separation 
On May 5, 2024 a patron reported to zoo personnel that they saw an agouti (a rodent species) bite the 11 year old male 
Campine chicken (#AV0544) that was housed in the same enclosure. The chicken was the only bird housed in this 
enclosure and had been housed its entire life with 3 cavies and 2 agouti without prior incident. Once notified, zoo staff 
quickly retrieved the chicken for medical assessment. The veterinarian elected to euthanize the chicken due to poor 
prognosis from the injuries it received. Birds may be subjected to adverse effects on welfare, health, or injury if housed 
with other animals that are not compatible. Facilities must ensure birds are housed with other compatible animals that do 
not prevent access to food, water, or shelter by individual animals, and are not known to be hazardous to the health and 
well-being of each other.  
 
Corrective action was implemented prior to the inspection on October 24, 2024 and avian species are no longer housed in 
this enclosure. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
